quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
def print_double(x):
   print(2 * x)

print_double(3)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Arguments[/h1]

All the function definitions we've looked at so far have been functions of zero arguments, which are called with empty parentheses. 
However, most functions take arguments.
The example below defines a function that takes one argument: [code format="py" codeId="331"]def print_with_exclamation(word):
   print(word + "!")
    
print_with_exclamation("spam")
print_with_exclamation("eggs")
print_with_exclamation("python")[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
spam!
eggs!
python!
>>>[/code]
[note]As you can see, the argument is defined inside the parentheses.[/note]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Arguments[/h1]

You can also define functions with more than one argument; separate them with commas.[code format="py" codeId="332"]def print_sum_twice(x, y):

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to define a function that prints "Yes", if its parameter is an even number, and "No" otherwise.
[!raw!]
{0} even(x):
   if x%2 == 0:
     {1}("Yes")
   {2}
     print("No")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Arguments[/h1]

Function arguments can be used as variables inside the function definition. However, they cannot be referenced outside of the function's definition. This also applies to other variables created inside a function.[code format="py" codeId="333"]def function([b]variable[/b]):
   [b]variable [/b]+= 1
   print([b]variable[/b])

function(7)
print([b]variable[/b])[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
8

NameError: name 'variable' is not defined
>>>[/code]
[note]Technically, [b]parameters [/b]are the variables in a function definition, and [b]arguments [/b]are the values put into parameters when functions are called.[/note]
